The word pay has reference to the one-eighth royalty owners because when they -- when they reach into the ground and take the gas, this leads to provide they must to pay a fair and reasonable value for it and when the word pay --
(Inaudible)
That's correct.
If you used it yourself, you must show that you are -- you've used it in such a way that it's consistent with the value of 11 cents.
Now, if you settle it at wellhead, I would think you would have some difficulty establishing that you attributed the price of 11 cents to it unless you got 11 cents at the wellhead for the gas.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That -- that's considerable.
That's not an overstatement say the least of it.
Well, I -- I -- but I don't think it's the same thing.
It's not the same thing which is the reason I phrased it the way I did Mr. Justice Black.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, how could -- how could they explain it at all if it's contributed unless they actually gotten the sentence of the court?
Well, some of these gases -- some of the gases are solid residue gas which was true in Panoma.
Panoma didn't deal with --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But they sell that for less than 11 cents and called it an attribution.

It would depend on what the residue gas there -- there -- if they would receive other -- that's just part of a gas, residue gas of the liquefiable hydrocarbon, the butanes, the propane, the natural gasoline, the income from that.

They would -- the nature of this proceeding would be a -- a proceeding to -- for them to establish whether or not they actually have pleaded this gas as though it was worth 11 cents and it would involve all of their revenues.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: How could Cities Service buy gas in Kansas after this order -- orders them?
You mean in a Kansas --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Legally without paying 11 cents.
Well, I would say -- I would put it this way.
How could Magnolia produce it unless --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I'm talking now about the one that gets it.
How could it buy for less than 11 cents legally under this order?
At the wellhead?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
(Inaudible)
They don't -- they're not required to attribute a nickel to it, the Cities Service.
It's the producers.
(Inaudible)
If -- if that was -- if they were buying whole gas at the wellhead, its producer could not produce it, unless it was getting as you say 11 cents for it.
(Inaudible)
If it wanted the gas.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. --
(Inaudible)
There's no argument about the impact of this order.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May -- may I ask you to turn to the order of the Commission.
I haven't read their interpreted order.
But would any interpretation change what need for me to -- to be plain on XXVIII in the jurisdictional statement where I got my order of the Commission just for convenience (Voice Overlap) --
I know.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Paragraph 17, that's the finding, isn't it?

That's the finding of the Commission by the premises finds, paragraph 17, finding 17 that curbs the fair and reasonable minimum price for gas that the wellhead in the Hugoton Field is 11 cents, then goes -- that's the finding.
That's -- they interpret that to mean anything of the cost -- that the wellhead price of gas is a fair price of 11 cents?
Yes --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is that subject to any other meaning on what it said?
Unless you would argue about whether price meant value there, I think that's what it means.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: All right, I don't care what that means.
Well, anyhow, that's what -- it says somebody who wants gas they have to pay 11 cents today, is that right?
I -- I think --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Does it mean that even?
Sir?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Does it mean that that if you want the -- the fair price at the wellhead is 11 cents.
I have great respect for ingenuity of the mind.
Tell me what it can mean other than what it says?
I think it means that -- that it has a fair and reasonable value of what -- 11 cents at the wellhead.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Just as an abstract proposition.
Well then if it -- it implements that, then we go to the order in page 29.
It is further ordered by the Commission.

It's furthered by the Commission order that all person, firm or corporations which take gas or cause gas to be taken from the Hugoton Gas Field in Kansas, shall -- certainly, the -- the Cities Service cost to be taken in the sense that --
No, it does not.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well --
The Commission has interpreted this order and the Supreme Court has interpret --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, let -- let me finish this one before we get to -- before you get to it -- shall as the condition precedent for withdrawal from the common source of supply, pay or attribute to all gas taken, except gas for the operation of leases at the wellhead until the further order is 11 cents.
Now, the Cities Service doesn't come in to the wellhead where it intervened in this whole process or chain of transaction, was at the wellhead, wasn't it?
Didn't -- when the Cities Service come in contact with the gas we're talking about at the wellhead, isn't it?
Did it have anything to do with this gas before the wellhead?
No.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No.
No.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, that's the well that it turns up and it wants the gas that's in there.
That's correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And how can it get that gas?
It can purchase it from the producer.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, can I get it any other way except having somebody who has control and hand it over to it.
That's correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And when it's handed over to the Cities Service because that's the 11 cents, is that correct?
That's correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And it has to do so because the Commission has ordered it that it can't get it for less.
It -- state action requires the seller to attribute the value to it.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: All right, attribute but Cities Service has to pay that 11 cents because Kansas has attributed 11 cents worth to that gas.
The seller can -- can sell it to somebody else from more 11 cents.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But it can't get it less than 11 cents --
No.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- to anybody, can he?
No, that's right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: So that whatever is -- whatever gas is involved that's between Cities Service and the seller is gas at the wellhead after all the physical transactions are completed and he can get that gas only if he can turn over 11 cents, is that right?
That's correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And that gas when it goes over the Cities Services by ordinary customer channeled going in and outside of Kansas, is that correct too?
After Cities Service purchases the gas.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But at that transaction, right there at the wellhead is what Cities Services is here about and what Kansas says you can't get -- put on it any other phase of transaction or monetary relationship except if you want it, you've got to pay at least 11 cents.
If Kansas does not tell that to Cities Service.
Kansas tells Magnolia.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Tells Magnolia.
That's correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That you can't sell it the Cities Service less than 11 cents, is that right?
If that's all you're going to do with it is sell it to Cities Service for 11 -- for less than 11 cents you can't produce --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But in fact, it sells it to a person who as a matter of vast range of business as interstate outlet for the gas he's getting, is that correct too?
If it sells it to the Cities Service, it sells it to such a person.
That's correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: All right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Suppose Magnolia buy or sells it for less than that, what can it be done to -- under Kansas law --
Well it --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- if it's a valid law.
The order says that they shall not take it out.
So it would be --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What sanction (Voice Overlap) --
-- from taking gas.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What sanction does your law provide for one who violates an order of your Commission?
Well, I -- there are some single provisions I suppose --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It's a criminal provision (Inaudible) --
For violation of an order?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
Well, the way the Kansas Commission has entered in this case is by so cost.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Does the -- is it a violation of your criminal statute?
No, no, I'm sure that's true.
(Inaudible)
That's -- let's say Corporation Commission of Kansas.
The obvious method of enforcing this order was to -- would be to prevent them from taking the gas out of the field.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You could enjoin it from violating this order, couldn't you?
Certainly.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And what -- are you really -- the colloquy between you and me get down to this that Kansas has done nothing to Cities Service, doesn't know Cities Service, doesn't care about Cities Service, but Magnolia -- and Magnolia is free not to tell to anybody to oblige, is that right?
As far as this order is concerned, Magnolia didn't sell to anybody, is that right?
As far as the order is concerned --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes.
-- that's -- that's correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Magnolia -- but if it sell, it sell -- it must sell at 11 -- for 11 cents or attribute 11 cents, is that right?
Yes, that's correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And Kansas doesn't know the existence of Cities Service, is that right?
Therefore, Cities Service is not involved.
Magnolia is free as a bird.
Therefore, nothing has happened.
Well, I -- I think you over simplify and overstate my position there.
I want to point out that this order was made to correct the continued monopolistic practices of the few pipeline companies out in the Kansas Hugoton Field.

And it was designed to correct correlative rights out there and that the price of gas in the Kansas Hugoton Field and the -- the conditions under which gas is produced in the Kansas Hugoton Field resulted from economic conditions peculiar to that field where a large number of small producers and landowners were facing drainage by reason of the monopolistic practices of the pipelines.
The -- there was a destructive competition among the small producers in trying to secure these pipeline connections.
And gas became a distress commodity and it was treated as a value -- a virtually valueless commodity.
It was blown in to air.

It was -- the wells were -- after the completion of the wells, they were -- they were blown for completion purposes carbon black plants sprang up in the area, manufacturing suit and using only about 92 or 9% or 10% of the energy of the gas.
In -- in short, a particle use and waste of this irreplaceable natural resource came into being.
And the evidence show that -- that there was a real relationship between treating this gas as a valueless or virtually valueless commodity and these wastes.
The record shows how this happened.
There were various wildcatters and the independents who first discovered the field.
There were just a few pipelines in the area.
It wasn't economically feasible to market this gas or to build a pipeline to market gas even from the largest wells or the 10 largest wells in the field.
You can't carry gas in the bucket like cooking oil.
You can't transport it from the truck.
You can't put it on a rail.
There's only one way to get it there and that's through pipelines.
And these pipelines constituted monopolies out there and the small independents and the producers were captive suppliers.
And they fought for connections and they lost some leases trying to get connections.
It cost about $25 to $30 million to build a pipeline.

And these pipeline companies, instead of giving the connections, and this is all in the record, instead of giving them connections, it would buy a lease right next to their leases and they drain their gas up from under them.
And so these independent producers, they wouldn't buy their gas.
They refuse to buy their gas.
Well, I'll have to continue this --

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Finish that in the morning.
-- in the morning.
